functions.cellular_process: PNPLA2, also known as Adipose Triglyceride Lipase (ATGL), is the rate-limiting enzyme for the hydrolysis of triacylglycerols stored in lipid droplets. The VCP cofactor UBXD8 traffics to the lipid droplet surface where it recruits VCP. The VCP-UBXD8 complex then binds directly to PNPLA2/ATGL. This interaction functions as a noncompetitive inhibitor by promoting the dissociation of PNPLA2/ATGL's essential coactivator, CGI-58 (also known as ABHD5). The separation of PNPLA2/ATGL from CGI-58 results in the inhibition of its lipase activity, leading to a suppression of lipolysis and an increase in lipid droplet size.
functions.effect_description: VCP, recruited by its cofactor UBXD8 to the surface of lipid droplets, indirectly inhibits the enzymatic activity of PNPLA2/ATGL by mediating the dissociation of its coactivator, CGI-58, which ultimately reduces the breakdown of stored fats.
biological_consequence: UBXD8 traffics to lipid droplets → UBXD8 recruits VCP to the lipid droplet surface → The VCP-UBXD8 complex binds to PNPLA2/ATGL → The coactivator CGI-58 is dissociated from PNPLA2/ATGL → PNPLA2/ATGL lipase activity is inhibited → Lipolysis is suppressed → Cellular lipid droplet size increases
specific_effects: The recruitment of VCP by UBXD8 promotes the dissociation of the activated PNPLA2/ATGL-CGI-58 complex.
The inhibition of PNPLA2/ATGL activity by the VCP-UBXD8 complex leads to an increase in lipid droplet size.

evidence.paper_title: Spatial regulation of UBXD8 and p97/VCP controls ATGL-mediated lipid droplet turnover
evidence.journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
evidence.relevant_quote: We exploit this interaction to show that UBXD8-mediated recruitment of p97/VCP to LDs increases LD size by inhibiting the activity of adipose triglyceride lipase (ATGL), the rate-limiting enzyme in triacylglycerol hydrolysis. Our findings show that UBXD8 binds directly to ATGL and promotes dissociation of its endogenous coactivator, CGI-58.

effect: VCP, recruited by its cofactor UBXD8 to the surface of lipid droplets, indirectly inhibits the enzymatic activity of PNPLA2/ATGL by mediating the dissociation of its coactivator, CGI-58, which ultimately reduces the breakdown of stored fats.
summary: VCP inhibits PNPLA2 to modulate lipolysis inhibition, ultimately affecting cellular lipid droplet size increases.
